w:r.w:t: Obie.Ai
https://obie.ai
Summary:
All of your team knowledge at your fingertips. Obie is a virtual assistant to help you make faster decisions, be more informed and get shit done without leaving slack.
Platforms: Slack
Financial model: Freemium model (pricing unknown as have to contact sales)
Key positives:
Fairly good design, relatively easy to use
On the market with proven market traction and hundreds of customers
Active on social and marketing scenes - could be considered a thought leader
Key negatives:
Only focussed on Slack- isn’t contextual across all workflows
Company structure is complicated - Obie is part of Tasytt - confusion as to who you’re transacting with.
No case studies/ in depth customer testimonies as to impact on workflow
No analytics unless in paid version
It pretends to be alive ‘my human workers are xyz.’ - this is a marmite subject with some liking it and others not
No custom NLP so there is a ramp-up period
Requires users to use an editor to create, edit and delete content into Obis format
Included in Free:
Included in paid:
Journal
https://usejournal.com/
Summary:
Search and remember information across your work apps and beyond. From conversations to files to interesting articles - anything you need, Journal helps you find it.
Platforms: Slack
Financial model: Unknown - currently waiting in list for trial
Key positives:
Unknown
Key negatives:
Unknown
Guru
www.getguru.com
Summary: Probably our most direct competitor in terms of function, value prop and pricing. However they require knowledge to be made in their cards. They can’t search files nor return files.
Platforms: Slack, browser extension (Google, Opera, Safari, Firefox), web app
Financial model: Free 21-Day trial then priced according to role/feature
Base: $5 user/month annual billing ($6 user/month on month)
Growth: $10 user/month annual billing ($12 user/month on month)
Base: $20 user/month annual billing ($24 user/month on month)
Pricing model/feature breakdown here > https://www.getguru.com/pricing/
Key positives:
Considered a market leader
Experienced team - previously sold a B2B business to Dell
Working on the problem since 2013
On the market with proven market traction and hundreds of customers
Active on social and marketing scenes - could be considered a thought leader
Some form of NLP/ML in order to surface cards
Verification and Q&A workflow allow for cards to be considered ‘trustworthy’ or not
Key negatives:
Poor design and overall ‘solution’ offered is another silo e.g. have to create Guru cards
Cumbersome signup flow - not sure what the value prop is at which point
High ramp up period - requires investment in time to add cards etc.
No analytics unless in paid version
Requires users to use an editor to create, edit and delete content into Gurus format
Butter.ai
www.butter.ai
Summary: Uses Slack to search connect apps for files in natural language. Can also request access to files in someones elses drive if they think it’s more relevant.
Platforms: Slack. We know they’re expanding to browsers soon.
Financial model: Free 14-Day trial then $4.99 per user/month (up to 20 users)
Key positives:
Experienced team - previously worked at Evernote
Working on the problem since 2015
Raised over $2 million in venture capital - inc. Dell, former Evernote CEO etc.
On the market with proven market traction and customers
Active on social and marketing scenes - could be considered a thought leader
Clear use of NLP/ML in order to surface cards
Key negatives:
Can only surface entire docs
Only works in Slack
Cumbersome signup flow - not sure what the value prop is at which point
No analytics
